Literature Review: Super-resolution fluorescence microscopy has revolutionized the field of polymer science, enabling researchers to investigate the intricate structures and dynamics of hydrogel nano- and microparticles, also known as microgels. These microgels, which can range in size from nanometers to micrometers, have unique properties that make them attractive models for studying polymer systems. In this review, we will discuss the various applications of super-resolution fluorescence microscopy to microgels, including their morphology, shape, and deformation, internal compartmentalization, cross-linker distribution and polarity, and dynamics and diffusion. We will also highlight the potential of super-resolution microscopy to access information beyond 3D localization, such as spectral and lifetime properties, and correlative imaging, and how this can provide new insights into the complexity of polymer systems.
